doc.ContractDescription: PROPELLER HUB ASSEMBLY AND BLADE SETS FOR 418' WMSL CUTTERS.

LEVERAGING HIGH RESOLUTION SPECTRA TO UNDERSTAND THE DISK AND RELATIVISTIC IRON LINE OF CYGNUS X-1 THERE IS CURRENTLY SIGNIFICANT DEBATE AS TO THE PHYSICAL MECHANISMS RESPONSIBLE FOR THE CONTINUUM OF X-RAY SPECTRALLY ``HARD STATES'' OF BLACK HOLE CANDIDATES (BHC) ACCRETING IN BINARIES. THIS DEBATE RANGES FROM THE BROADER ISSUE OF WHETHER OR NOT THERE IS A SIGNIFICANT CONTRIBUTION TO THE X-RAY BAND FROM AN OUTFLOW OR JET, TO MORE NARROWLY FOCUSED ISSUES WITHIN GIVEN CLASSES OF MODELS. THE HARD X-RAY EMISSION HAS TRADITIONALLY BEEN ATTRIBUTED TO A COMPTONIZING THERMAL CORONA, WHERE THE CORONA LIES CENTRAL TO A TRUNCATED OUTER THIN DISK. HOWEVER, IF THE CORONA IS DRIVEN OUTWARDS BY RADIATIVE PRESSURE COULD IT INSTEAD OVERLAY THE INNER DISK? CAN THE OPTICALLY THICK, GEOMETRICALLY THIN DISK EXTEND INWARD NEARLY TO THE INNERMOST STABLE CIRCULAR ORBIT? AT THE VERY LEAST, DOES THE DISK EXTEND DEEP ENOUGH INTO THE POTENTIAL WELL SUCH THAT STUDY OF THE RELATIVISTICALLY BROADENED FLUORESCENCE LINE YIELDS A MEASUREMENT OF THE BLACK HOLE SPIN? OBSERVATIONS OF THE BRIGHT, PERSISTENTLY EMITTING BHC CYGNUS X-1 HAVE PLAYED A CENTRAL ROLE IN THESE DEBATES. THE MAJORITY OF THE OBSERVATIONS OF CYG X-1, HOWEVER, HAVE BEEN PERFORMED WITH THE ROSSI X-RAY TIMING EXPLORER (RXTE). AS THE DISK SPECTRUM PEAKS AT ENERGIES 1 KEV, RXTE DOES NOT DIRECTLY MEASURE THE DISK COMPONENT. FURTHERMORE, RXTE LACKS THE SPECTRAL RESOLUTION TO DESCRIBE THE DETAILS OF THE BROADENED FE LINE WELL-ENOUGH TO ATTEMPT A LINE-BASED SPIN MEASUREMENT. CHANDRA, XMM-NEWTON, AND SUZAKU SPECTRA, ON THE OTHER HAND, ALL HAVE BOTH LOW ENERGY COVERAGE AND MODERATE-TO-HIGH SPECTRAL RESOLUTION IN THE FE BAND. THE LATTER TWO INSTRUMENTS ARE ESPECIALLY WELL-SUITED FOR MEASUREMENTS OF THE DISK AND FE LINE REGION. CHANDRA OBSERVATIONS, HOWEVER, POINT OUT TWO DETAILS OFTEN IGNORED IN CCD STUDIES OF CYG X-1: THE IONIZED WIND OF THE SECONDARY, AND THE DUST SCATTERING HALO. THE LATTER WILL ALWAYS AFFECT DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS WITH XMM-NEWTON, AND WILL AFFECT DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS WITH SUZAKU IF SPECTRAL VARIABILITY HAS OCCURRED WITHIN A FEW TENS OF THOUSANDS OF SECONDS PRIOR TO THE OBSERVATION. THE IONIZED WIND (AND THE ASSOCIATED COLD, OPTICALLY THICK ``ACCRETION DIPS'' THAT PREFERENTIALLY OCCUR NEAR ORBITAL PHASE ZERO, I.E., SUPERIOR CONJUNCTION) AFFECT BOTH THE DISK CONTINUUM MEASUREMENTS AND THE FE BAND. WE HAVE RECENTLY COMPLETED CHANDRA STUDIES OF BOTH THE DUST HALO AND THE ORBITAL PHASE-DEPENDENT IONIZED WIND IN CYG X-1. WE PROPOSE TO USE THE KNOWLEDGE GAINED FROM THESE STUDIES TO MORE CAREFULLY EXAMINE THREE DATASETS: 1) A SET OF SUZAKU OBSERVATIONS, WHICH WE WILL USE TO EXAMINE THE DISK AND FE LINE REGION OF CYG X-1, 2) A MULTI-SATELLITE SIMULTANEOUS OBSERVATION OF CYG X-1 WHICH WE WILL USE TO EXAMINE THE EFFECT AND APPEARANCE OF BOTH THE DUST HALO AND IONIZED WIND IN EACH X-RAY DETECTOR, AS WELL AS TO EXAMINE THE (BRIGHT SOURCE) CROSS-CALIBRATION AMONG X-RAY DETECTORS, AND 3) A SET OF XMM-NEWTON OBSERVATIONS WHICH WE WILL SPECIFICALLY COMPARE TO THE SUZAKU CCD SPECTRA TO DETERMINE IF ONE CAN DESCRIBE THE FE LINE SPECTRUM WITH A SET OF MODELS THAT SHARE A COMMON BLACK HOLE SPIN.

doc.ContractDescription: WE PROPOSE TO ADVANCE OUR DEVELOPMENT OF THREE-DIMENSIONALLY INTEGRATED ACTIVE PIXEL SENSORS FOR X-RAY ASTRONOMY. OUR GOAL IS TO DEMONSTRATE A SENSOR THAT HAS THE SUPERB X-RAY DETECTION AND SPECTRAL RESOLUTION PERFORMANCE OF STATE-OF-THE-ART CCDS TOGETHER WITH ALL OF THE ENORMOUS ADVANTAGES INHERENT IN ACTIVE PIXEL SENSOR ARCHITECTURE. IN OUR CURRENT APRA PROGRAM WE HAVE SUCCESSFULLY DEMONSTRATED A BACK-ILLUMINATED, THREE-DIMENSIONALLY INTEGRATED X-RAY SENSOR WITH A 5O-MICRON-THICK DEPLETION REGION. WE HAVE OBTAINED A SPECTRAL RESOLUTION BETTER THAN 190 EV (FWHM) AT 5.9 KEY WITH THIS DEVICE USING WITH A MULTIPLE-SAMPLE READOUT SCHEME. OUR SENSOR HAS EXCELLENT CHARGE COLLECTION CHARACTERISTICS, AND ITS SPECTRAL RESOLUTION IS NEARLY READ-NOISE LIMITED. OUR EXHAUSTIVE STUDIES OF THIS DEVICE HAVE PROVIDED US DETAILED INSIGHT INTO ITS LIMITATIONS, AND HERE WE PROPOSE TO IMPLEMENT A VARIETY OF SPECIFIC DESIGN AND PROCESS CHANGES TO PRODUCE A NEXT-GENERATION SENSOR WITH MUCH BETTER PERFORMANCE, ESPECIALLY AT SOFT (E<2 KEY) ENERGIES. SPECIFICALLY, WE WILL EXPLOIT THE INHERENT DESIGN FLEXIBILITY OF UNIQUE, THREE-DIMENSIONALLY INTEGRATED CIRCUIT FABRICATION TECHNOLOGY AT MIT LINCOLN LABORATORY TO ACHIEVE MUCH HIGHER RESPONSIVITY WHILE ENHANCING TRANSISTOR DESIGN AND FABRICATION PROCESS DETAILS TO REDUCE NOISE. WE WILL ALSO EVALUATE A NEW PIXEL DESIGN THAT SUPPORTS ON-CHIP EVENT IDENTIFICATION AND THEREFORE ENABLES FUTURE, VERY-HIGH-THROUGHPUT, EVENT-DRIVEN SENSORS. OUR PROPOSED PROGRAM CAPITALIZES ON SIGNIFICANT, LONG-TERM INVESTMENT IN SENSOR FABRICATION TECHNOLOGY BY THE DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE. IT ALSO TAKES ADVANTAGE OF CURRENT DEVELOPMENT ACTIVITIES AT MIT LINCOLN LABORATORY TO MINIMIZE FABRICATION COSTS TO NASA. AT THE CONCLUSION OF OUR PROPOSED PROGRAM WE WILL HAVE PROVIDED NASA WITH THE CAPABILITY TO DESIGN AND FABRICATE ACTIVE PIXEL X-RAY SENSORS WITH THE PERFORMANCE REQUIRED FOR HIGH-ENERGY ASTROPHYSICS RESEARCH FROM SPACE. WE WILL ALSO HAVE ESTABLISHED THE FOUNDATION FOR A NEW GENERATION OF FLIGHT INSTRUMENTATION.

IGF::OT::IGF NASA IS DEVELOPING METHODS TO COLLECT AND CONVERT LOCAL RESOURCES SUCH AS MARTIAN AIR (MAINLY CARBON DIOXIDE, CO2) INTO OXYGEN THAT CAN BE USED DURING THE MISSION. THE OBJECTIVE OF THIS PROJECT IS TO PROTECT SUCH EQUIPMENT FROM DUST THAT MAY BE SUCKED IN WITH THE CO2. WE PROPOSED AN INNOVATIVE DUST FILTRATION SYSTEM THAT IS IDEALLY SUITED FOR LONG DURATION OPERATION IN MARS BECAUSE IT WORKS WELL IN A LOW PRESSURE ENVIRONMENT AND IT IS ESSENTIALLY SELF-CLEANING. THE SYSTEM IS BASED ON TWO MECHANISMS OF DUST FILTRATION THAT HAVE BEEN TESTED SEPARATELY AND SUCCESSFULLY IN PHASE I. IN PHASE II, PARAMETRIC TESTS WILL BE PERFORMED WITH SIMULATED MARS DUST AND UNDER SIMULATED MARS ENVIRONMENT TO OPTIMIZE EACH MECHANISM. THEN THE TWO MECHANISMS WILL BE COMBINED IN A PROTOTYPE AND TESTED. THE PROTOTYPE WILL BE DELIVERED TO NASA FOR POTENTIAL FUTURE TESTS IN THE ZERO GRAVITY AIRPLANE AND IN COMBINATION WITH THE EQUIPMENT TO BE PROTECTED.
